content: today i'm going to be making modular docks but more importantly i'm going to
be demonstrating how you can make the same terrain out of whatever
material you happen to have available hey guys welcome back to blackmagic
craft this week's episode is sponsored by the dragon trappers lodge and they're
a company that provides really cool models that you can 3d print
at home when they showed me the renders for
this month i saw this crazy shark source model and i knew that i had to print it
out and paint it as well as this really neat pirate rat
it's just super cool my gut instinct was to make a cool little diorama but i also
thought it would be a really good opportunity to make some
modular nautical terrain so i turned the decision over to
my patreon supporters and they overwhelmingly supported the idea of
modular docs so that's what i am making today modular docs i
really wanted to demonstrate the same project using
three completely different materials whatever you have on hand whatever tools
whatever materials crack them out just make things with
them i kept them low so that they're about the same height
as my basic tiles this is a great way to use them to transition
from land city streets whatever to water on top of your favorite battle mat
i also avoided adding any kind of like water splashing effects around the posts
so that they could be used as generic wood platforms in any setting
like a cave they could also be used as bridges
keeping your terrain as generic and modular as possible
is a great way to get the most bang for your buck out of your efforts as a
builder so now let's get building
what seems like an obvious choice for this project and really it is a good one
i'm not using balsa wood because for a lot of people including myself
balsa wood isn't readily available in large quantities for a good price
but basic crafting wood like dowels coffee stir sticks popsicle sticks that
sort of thing this is something that just about
everyone can get their hands on unfortunately these kinds of craft
sticks need to be carved up to make them look
more like old hand-hewn lumber instead of well
craft sticks you can do this with a knife if that's all you've got it works
just as well but it's a slow process if you happen to
have a rotary tool you can make very fast work of this by using a sanding
drum it's really hard to get visible wood
grain in the wood which i know is ironic but it's the
truth and it's one of the reasons i often don't use wood to make miniature
wood things what you can do is shoot for uneven
beveled edges on the pieces and kind of roughen them up a bit and that
will make them look more like timber now for the posts and this will be true
of all three materials i made them one inch tall i also marked
out half inch increments on them as this would be the level of the actual
docking to bring it in line with half inch thick tiles
obviously you're going to want to adjust this to suit whatever thickness of tiles
you use regularly if you use one inch thick
tiles make your docks taller if you use thinner tiles
make them shorter you want to cut two thinner dowels to
act as support rods i made these six inches long the docks
end up being six inches by two inches which is a nice
form factor to work on a one inch grid and with one inch base
tiles a dab of pva glue on your posts is all you need to attach the support rods
if you're making a lot of these docks i suggest making all of the side pieces at
the same time so you can align them with each other
and so that they have time to dry and bond well before moving on
you can cut your planking at two inches long or slightly longer if you want a
little bit of an overhang i don't love using super glue on wood
but to attach the first and last plank super glue and
some accelerant is very helpful this way you can get your basic frame
secure and then use pva to place the remaining planks
pva is a lot stronger on wood but it takes a lot longer to dry
the nice thing about using it to place the planks though is that you have
working time so you can kind of slide them and move them around
to fit and sit the way you want if you end up with a dock that's kind of wibbly
wobbly and posts that are maybe a bit wonky just snap one of them off then
glue it back in place while firmly holding down the other posts
this way you can ensure that all of the posts are making good contact with the
table and that's it wood is probably the most
durable option here and it looks pretty good
the downside is that it's a bit fiddly to work with and assemble
and despite actually being real wood it can be very difficult to get it to
look like wood at scale it's really hard to get any kind of wood grain that
visually stands out but for long lasting pieces
this is probably your best bet well if foam is your go-to material for
this project it's safe to assume that you are well versed in foam crafting and
that you probably have a hot wire table at your disposal
if not well the other two materials may be a better choice
you want to make some quarter inch by quarter inch strips to create the posts
and the support rails now these end up being a bit chunkier in
size than you might want visually but you have to be careful when making
delicate items out of foam if you make pieces that are too thin
well they're going to end up being really flimsy and might be too fragile
to work or use for the planking cut some thinner strips
out of some half inch foam i just eyeballed the thickness that i thought
would be just thick enough to hold up but thin enough to still look okay which
is about 3 16 of an inch some great looking wood grain can be
added to the pieces using a wire brush you can also hand carve in the wood
grain with a sharp tool or a pencil which will give a less realistic but
more dramatic wood grain for the posts you want to chamfer the
edges of the piece with a sharp knife before applying the wood grain this will
give you something that looks a little bit more like a rounded
wood timber the support timbers are again cut to 6
inches long but in this case with foam you need a bit more support
and you're going to want to put end pieces and
a middle rail the best way to assemble the frame is with some dabs of
pva glue and a push pin you can actually use a push pin through the post
and intersecting frame pieces all in one go and you can just leave this pin in
place for some more durability if you don't like the way that big push
pin head looks you can actually just snip it off before pushing the pin all
the way in to make the planks look more realistic i find it helps to
cut them with slightly wavy cuts on each side so if you're using that half inch
wide strip cut both edges then do a cut in the
middle and don't worry about being perfectly straight just freehand it this
will give you some great wavy variety in your widths and this is going to look
really good once assembled in my opinion foam ends up with the best
looking option on the table but it's definitely the most difficult
to make and easily the least durable so there's a
big trade-off here this would be my preferred method for a
group of adult gamers who play in a space where the terrain never needs
to be transported if you travel with terrain play with
strangers who might not handle your pieces carefully
or if you game with kids this probably is not the best option for you
but if it's looks that matter most this is the best fit
now before i demonstrate how to build these docks out of paper
i want to take a second to highlight this week's sponsor
the dragon trappers lodge is a monthly patreon-based service for getting
3d printable miniatures for your tabletop games every single month there
is a unique gargantuan scale dragon model
as well as the heroes to slay it oh and there's also a mounted creature for your
minis to ride on every month which is really neat they
all come with cool custom bases and many of the models also come with several
different hand and weapon options a nice bonus is that each month
they provide 5th edition dungeons and dragon stat blocks for the dragons
these models are less focused on generic monsters or hordes and more focused on
just really cool characters the models are
really flavorful and surprisingly unique which is a difficult thing to do in
such a growing market of printable minis these ones really stand out i think it's
safe to say they're making some of the most
original and fresh miniatures on the market today they're pushing the
boundaries of what gaming miniatures look like seriously
you can get a rap pirate and a huge shark
source model it's awesome they all come as
pre-supported files making it drag and drop and
really user friendly if you want to get some of these really cool models from
december's theme well you want to jump over to their patreon and join up before
the month is over i'll put a link in the video description
so you can check them out for yourself i know
you can't resist this shark asaurus seriously you need this in your life
yes you can totally make these docks entirely out of paper products
for the frame i'm using medium weight chipboard which is just very
dense paper it's basically the same sort of material
that's used for matte boards in picture frames you could replace this
with thinner cardstock from something like a cereal box if that's all you can
get you'll just need to make a few more layers for the frame to make a sturdy
frame you want it to be one piece so start by cutting out a two
inch by six inch rectangle well actually a couple of them then you want to cut
out an inner rectangle leaving a border that's about a quarter inch all the way
around you can measure out and draw this with a
ruler or just use some mad finger gauging skills if you got them
now carefully cut out the inner rectangle ensuring not to over
cut and weaken the corners you can then use your first one
as a guide to lay out the rest then just glue the layers together now if you're
using chipboard type material like i am two layers is enough if you're using
thinner material you may need three or four layers in the end the
results are going to be the same if you want you can bevel the edges of
the paper to make it look a bit more like timber but
realistically you won't see much of this frame in the finished
product you can make planks out of the same medium weight chipboard material
which will be nice and sturdy or again you can absolutely just use thin
cardstock from food packaging an easy way to do this is
to cut a rectangle of material slightly wider than your frame
you can use a knife to score some wood grain lines into it before cutting it if
you'd like this effect isn't great but it can help
to make it look a little bit less like paper in the end with this
material it's best to apply your planks to the frame
first and then add your posts and the post is where you need to get a little
bit clever with the material you can use basic construction paper to
make some decent looking wood posts though
simply cut some strips making them as wide as you want your posts to be
tall from there you can just roll them up to make logs
it helps to dampen the paper a bit with water before applying a
thin layer of pva glue then just roll them up until you get the diameter you
want and cut off any excess with wet glue soaked sticky fingers you
can kind of smush up the outside and sort of hide that paper seam
by hydrating the paper and flattening it
with your fingers or your fingernail this step sort of burrs up the paper a
bit which actually helps to simulate a more rougher wood texture place your
planked frame on a scrap bit of foam and just hot glue the posts in place you
could use pva as well for this if you aren't in a
hurry but using hot glue is going to be a lot faster and if you are going to use
hot glue it's really important to make sure that those paper logs are
really well dried before attaching them paper is obviously the least realistic
looking option here but given its cost and the effort involved
it's a pretty great option if that's all you have to work with it's also a very
durable option it actually might be more durable than
wood in a lot of cases as it wouldn't shatter
at the joint if you were to say drop it on the floor and the paper stays a
little bit flexible this is definitely the best option for
gaming with young kids if that's your situation
especially since they won't mind the less realistic
look and there you go the same basic idea made with three totally different
materials i should mention that with the foam and the paper before
painting you're going to want to put on a coat of mod podge or watered down pva
glue to harden it up and make it a little bit
more durable i think each of these materials has pros and
cons and the best option depends on what you prioritize
your choice might be made for you by your own limitations when it comes to
tools or materials but if you have access to all of them you can really
just pick what looks the best or what best suits
your gaming habits or simply what option you would find the
most enjoyable to make in bulk and make sure to give that aspect good
consideration if you plan on making a bunch of these it's pretty important to
know which one you're going to enjoy doing the most
over and over again of course you could also mix elements from all three to
create the perfect option for you personally i like the idea of the foam
planks visually but would prefer a wood frame for
durability there's nothing saying you can't combine them
well i hope you guys enjoyed this week's video and

got to get a little resourceful and you know
don't limit yourself saying well i can't do this because i don't have x
